Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Contact Charge Electrophoresis for Mobile Microfluidics

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Bishop
1351704

The recent discovery of a new type of electrophoresis, contact-charge electrophoresis (CCEP), is interesting, but is not broadly useful per se in that the phenomenon results in a charged particle or droplet oscillating between two electrodes. The PI has drawn out a roadmap of how to break out of the oscillation and linearize the motion by using "ratchets" to move the particles through long distances and to use the ratchets to separate particles in microfluidic devices. He has also laid out plans to understand the basic mechanism of CCEP using new simulation tools and to validate his models in his laboratory.

This new ability to manipulate small particles will have an additional impact on many technologies such as those that require particle separations or technologies used in electronic displays, cell sorting, and DNA sequencing.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In 1745, the Scotch Benedictine monk Andrew Gordon suspended a small metal sphere by a fine silk thread between two electrified bells. He marveled as the sphere moved back and forth between the bells, creating a gentle ringing sound. Years later, Benjamin Franklin combined Gordon’s chimes with his recent invention, the lightning rod, to provide an audible warning of approaching thunderstorms to further his own investigations of atmospheric electricity. These early investigations mark the first use of electricity to perform mechanical work, that is, the first electric motors. A century later, Michael Faraday demonstrated an alternative motor based on electromagnetic forces, and Franklin’s electrostatic motor faded into the annals of history. But now this ca. 250-year-old technology has found new life in powering motions and mechanical functions at the micro- and nanoscales, where it offers performance benefits over existing approaches. In a process called contact charge electrophoresis (CCEP), a conductive object (e.g., a solid particle or liquid droplet) is first charged by contact with an electrified surface and then moved by the accompanying electric field. This CAREER project has advanced our fundamental understanding of CCEP and demonstrated its utility in powering the active components of microfluidic systems (e.g., mixing, pumping, cargo transport) useful in applications such as Point-of-Care diagnostics.

 

We developed predictive models and simulation tools that describe the complex dynamics of conductive particles moving between electrified surfaces. These predictions were validated by quantitative experiments on micron-scale particles moving through fluid environments. Building on our fundamental understanding of CCEP, we developed and demonstrated strategies for directing the motions of particles and droplets using ratcheted channels or asymmetric particles (so-called Janus particles). These capabilities enable the rational design of battery-powered operations such cargo transport, fluid mixing, and particle separations within microfluidic systems. We have also discovered how multiple particles oscillating by CCEP can interact and synchronize to create cooperative traveling wave motions, which are potentially useful in powering the locomotion of micro-scale robots.  In a forward-looking perspective article, we outlined our current understanding of CCEP and highlighted future opportunities for CCEP in the areas of soft robotics and nano-scale motors.

 

This CAREER project supported the Ph.D. research of three graduate students, who have all defended their dissertations and moved on to research opportunities in academia (UCSD), industry (Intel), and consulting (CNA). These students worked diligently to mentor several undergraduate researchers, who made significant contributions to the project outcomes as reflected by their authorship on peer-reviewed publications. In collaboration with the Upward Bound Math and Science Center (UBMS), we created an interactive research experience for visiting high school students from communities underrepresented in science and engineering. During a 10-week program, the visiting students worked closely with their mentors to create microfluidic systems that use CCEP to transport and separate particle dispersions. This structured research experience helped participating students to recognize and develop their abilities in math and science and student mentors to become more effective educators. The research and educational objectives of this project were further integrated through the development and deployment of a new course on Bayesian data analysis, which emphasizes the foundational relationships between models and data that underlie the scientific method.
